subject: history
title: Press, Literature & Nationalist Movement
description: Role of newspapers, books, and writers in freedom struggle

rows.examples:
**Bengali**: Amrita Bazar Patrika (Sisir Kumar Ghosh), Bengalee (Surendranath Banerjee), Sanjivani, Yugantar (revolutionary)

**Hindi**: Kesari & Mahratta (Tilak - Marathi/English), Pratap (Ganesh Shankar Vidyarthi), Independent (Motilal Nehru)

**English**: The Hindu (G. Subramania Iyer), Hindustan Times, Indian Mirror, Bombay Chronicle, Young India (Gandhi), Harijan (Gandhi)

**Urdu**: Comrade & Hamdard (Mohamed Ali), Al-Hilal (Maulana Azad)

**Tamil**: Swadesamitran

**Vernacular Press Act (1878)**: Lytton; targeted Indian language papers; repealed by Ripon (1881)

**Newspapers Act (1908)**: Against revolutionary papers

**Indian Press Act (1910)**: Security deposits; forfeiture

**Defence of India Act (1915)**: Wartime censorship
rows.exam:
Vernacular Press Act (1878) = Lytton = Gagging Act

Repealed by Ripon (1881)

rows.examples:
**V.D. Savarkar**: 'The Indian War of Independence, 1857' (banned by British)

**Bankim Chandra**: 'Anandamath' (Vande Mataram song)

**Rabindranath Tagore**: 'Gitanjali', 'Gora', 'Ghare-Baire'; wrote national anthem 'Jana Gana Mana'

**Subramanya Bharati**: Tamil nationalist poet

**Mohammad Iqbal**: 'Saare Jahan Se Achha'; also proposed Pakistan idea

**Premchand**: Hindi/Urdu novelist; depicted peasant life
rows.exam:
**Anandamath = Vande Mataram**

**Tagore = Jana Gana Mana + Nobel (1913)**

**Iqbal = Saare Jahan Se Achha**

rows.examples:
• Created national consciousness
• Exposed British exploitation
• United people across regions through print
• Spread revolutionary & reformist ideas
• Educated masses about political rights
• British feared press power → repressive laws
• Many editors jailed for 'sedition'
rows.exam:
Press = 'Oxygen' of freedom movement

Tilak, Gandhi, Azad all editors

examTips.critical: Remember editor-newspaper pairs: Tilak-Kesari; Gandhi-Young India/Harijan; Mohamed Ali-Comrade; Bankim-Anandamath-Vande Mataram; Tagore-Jana Gana Mana
